posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
image 1920×643 134 KB

image 1920×643 134 KB

image 1920×643 134 KB

Synapse is a dynamic library designed specifically for vision processing on FRC co-processors (e.g., Raspberry Pi, Jetson, or similar). The goal is to provide teams with an efficient, easy-to-integrate solution for processing camera data outside the roboRIO, freeing up valuable CPU resources and enabling more advanced algorithms, without locking to user to using speicific algorithms and allowing custom code to be ran natively.

Custom pipelines are integrated automatically into the UI, without modifying the UI code itself, and have settings rendered the same as any other pipeline would have, and their settings are verified automatically

All of the settings are validated automatically via constraints saved inside the runtime and verified in runtime

Custom pipelines are written exactly the same way as the built in ones, even camera calibration is a pipeline .

Basic Apriltag Processing - Due to the dynamic nature of the library, expanding this was delayed until everything was functionally working and communicating since once the whole runtime knows to work with A pipeline it doesn’t matter what is written inside it.

Fully Featured UI written in React with support for infinitley many pipelines and cameras - The runtime is limited by the hardware, not the software

Basic integrated camera calibration - This will be expanded in the very soon future but currently works for ChAruco calibration boards

Settings Access both from UI and NT - almost everything is modifiable everywhere (Some stuff that aren’t modifiable from NT include device restarting & network config)

Settings Verification API - allows pipelines to not worry about verifying or clamping values, the settings API handles that for them.

Partial Documentation - While not all of the project is currently documented (e.g robot interfacing works but is not documented at the moment of writing this), a large majority is.

Static Camera Identifiers - persists between reboots

ProtoBuf messaging between UI and backend - Any UI can be implemented for the user’s needs as long as it can communicate with the runtime with the messages it requires.

Base Robot interfacing with the runtime - While not very performant at the moment for multiple tag results from the AprilTag Pipeline, future improvements are already being worked on and planned.

Custom pipelines support Custom pipelines can be written using the same way the built in ones are - with Python Code Deployment to a coprocessor is handled in a simmilar fashion to Robot Code deployment.

Custom pipelines can be written using the same way the built in ones are - with Python

Code Deployment to a coprocessor is handled in a simmilar fashion to Robot Code deployment.

Ability to run the runtime outside of the robot - Since this is wirtten with Python, no special compiling is needed to run on any machine, including your own development computer.

Easy to install PyPi package to work with the project

Synapse Web UI 1919×919 66.5 KB

Synapse Web UI 1919×919 66.5 KB

Synapse Web UI 1919×919 66.5 KB

Better Apriltag Pipeline

Color Detection Pipeline

Better Results API

More types of settings

Recording Camera Output

GitHub Repository - All of the code is OpenSource and hosted under the gnu v3 license Documentation Discord Server

A lot of thanks and appriciation for the following people:

@nstrike For helping setting up the vendordep library for the robot interfacing, style choices with the UI, networking, support and encouragement with the project

Chris from team 5561 For helping setting up the discord community and styling choices with the UI, support and encouragement with the project

@Peter_Johnson For helping and answering endless questions and issues setting up CSCore within python and versioning

My Team, Ionic Bond 9738 For giving this project a place to live and exist both on the robot and in person

DISCLAIMER: THIS PROJECT IS STILL IN ALPHA AND ISN’T FINISHED, TAKE THAT INTO CONSIDERATION
Really cool project! I cant wait to see how this evolves!

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: I look forward to seeing this grow!

posts.name: Konnor/RetroBuzz | 5517AM
posts.cooked: I plan on trying it out when I get the chance and will likely use it during our 2026 season as I have heard lots of great things about it.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Very intriguing. I have wanted custom processing/filtering in PhotonVision, and maybe this is the way to go.

One thing to maybe strive for during development is being able to “easily” modify a standard pipline to add custom features. Presumably, one could copy-paste an existing pipeline, but inheriting and overriding is even better.

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Also, from looking at the documentation, currently your Pipeline appears to be “image in ==> image out”. However, don’t forget that the image processing is (in my experience) a pretty small part of the process (I was going to say “minor”, but clearly it is important).  The majority of the work has often been processing the data from the image.

So, to be more concrete: processing the image looking for Apriltags is very likely to be the same for everyone. Where I would want to customize is taking all the found tags and filtering and computing to produce poses which are sent to the robot.

But the architecture looks very promising.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Would you be willing to add an exception to GNU v3 license for Cuda and other accelerated computing libraries?

Something like:

(taken from lc0/src/neural/backends/cuda/cuda_common.h at 2fc51522e72a126ec6d492a01d4ca3a0f3c2864d · LeelaChessZero/lc0 · GitHub here)

Otherwise it arguably breaks the license terms to add support for closed source but available with the purchase of a device GPU libraries, which might be an issue down the line.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: Sure thing! Added In this PR

link_counts.title: Added license for cuda by DanPeled · Pull Request #107 · DanPeled/Synapse · GitHub

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: The data from the pipeline is going to have its own API as I stated in the planned features, a lot is planned for it The AprilTag Pipeline specifically is going to go through a lot of changes, and all the detection for apriltags will be moved outside of it to it’s own class that the pipeline will just use.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: Both options would work out of the box technically

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: So is the difference between this and PhotonVision, that it’s easier to add custom pipelines?

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: Yes, that’s one of the main differences. This is meant to be a dynamic way to interact with vision, adapting to changing needs. While it’s natural to compare it to PhotonVision, I don’t think it’s a fair comparison. These are two different projects: both run vision on a coprocessor for FRC and share many similarities, but they approach the problem in very different ways.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Then it’s not clear to me what the additional features are here.

“Adapting to changing needs” just tells me I can add custom code more easily with different words.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
Yes, it’s designed to make creating and expanding custom pipelines easier.

This project was never intended to compete with PhotonVision. The two serve different purposes. While PhotonVision focuses on a ready-to-use vision solution, this project is built for teams who want a flexible foundation to run their own custom vision code on a coprocessor. That means it might go far beyond what some teams need or want—but it’s there for anyone who wants that level of control.

Looking back, I realize I should have made this distinction clearer in the original post.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
So is there some Synapse API that makes it easier to develop custom pipelines? Or are users just using the same frameworks underlying frameworks?

The way I see it, if a team has the resources to develop their own pipeline, they’re capable of going all the way (it’s not that difficult if you’re willing to get into it). Basically Python and a systemd service in most cases.

And those that don’t have the resources, just use one of the existing solutions. PhotonVision on a Pi is very cheap and takes like 5 minutes to get running for example, and has the best robot side API in my opinion.

So I guess I’m confused on how many “in-between” teams this really serves?

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked:
viggy96:

So is there some Synapse API that makes it easier to develop custom pipelines? Or are users just using the same frameworks underlying frameworks?

All pipelines, whether built-in or custom, are handled the same way. Synapse automatically discovers them, and they’re all written using the same structure. The UI doesn’t know in advance which pipelines exist, except for the CalibrationPipeline . Instead, all settings, configuration, and data are loaded dynamically.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: Seems very interesting, and the more competition there is (in anything really), the better. As a suggestion, you might want to add object detection functionality (using Rockchip NPU, Google Coral, Hailo 8, etc.) once you finish the other pipelines, similar to PhotonVision.

posts.name: Dan Peled
posts.cooked: This is definitely something that will be considered, once the results API I mentioned in the post will be done I think development will definitely go towards expanding the existing pipelines and adding more pre-built ones
